Yeah, that tends to happen here.  :)

> I was just asking how to solve a CGI programming problem with Python
> in a RESTful way!
>
> I can not do HTTP authentication from a Python CGI script, can I?  I
> tried to look for examples or to figure it out but I have been
> unsuccessful.  And then somebody explained to me that HTTP auth. is
> not used by banks etc. on the internet, because it is not secure
> enough.  For my civilization like game HTTP auth. could be secure
> enough, but oh well, I don't know how to implement it from a CGI
> script anyway.

Assuming that all banks use HTTPS, HTTP Auth no less secure than the use of
a session cookie.  The main reason that it's not used (I suspect) is that
the banks cannot control the look of the dialog box.  Another possbility is
that banks (wrongly) believe that HTTP Auth is less secure because it passes
plaintext user/pwd in every request.  But this is no less true of passing
the user/pwd from an HTML form.  The security is in the use of HTTPS.
Certainly, using HTTP Digest Auth (as opposed to Basic) would protect the
password, but the extra measure is pointless if using HTTPS.

One advantage to HTTP Auth (as opposed to an HTML form) is that you can
potentially access any resource in a collection directly instead of going to
a single "entrypoint".  As to whether you can handle HTTP Basic or Digest
Auth through Python CGI, I don't really know.  If you have access to all of
the HTTP request headers, then I'd think you should be able to manually
implement it.  Though it may be necessary to be running a SAPI module
instead of a CGI program...

> So I was thinking about setting up the "login" page with HTTPS and
> this then calls a CGI script generating a "sessionID" passed along
> with HIDDEN HTML FORM parameters on every next page, and then all
> the next pages don't need SSL.  The nice thing for me is then that I
> don't have to change source code when the SSL part is turned on
> later.  I can develop it using Apache on my laptop (without SSL).
> Or is there a more RESTful way to do it?

This technique would be no better than using a session cookie, in my
opinion, and a whole lot more work (how would you handle GET requests?).
Placing the sessionID in the URL's query string would be another way to go.
Of course, there are a good number of opinions go around about what is the
right or wrong way of doing this and it is a far from settled topic.

As for the original topic, could you give a slightly more detailed example
who can and cannot access cities, what access is allowed in those cases, and
how you are currently doing it (or planning on doing it)?

Seairth
